importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the incident when the cargo plane skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport and resulted in two fatalities.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time the Boeing aircraft went off course upon arrival from Dubai, leading to the runway skid and collision with a security patrol car.

keyTakeAways: A cargo plane operated by ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport and crashed into the sea, killing two airport staff in a vehicle it struck.
The aircraft, a Boeing model, broke in two upon impact and was left partially submerged with significant damage to its front section and tail.
The four crew members onboard were treated for injuries, and there was no cargo on board.
The flight was operated under Emirates flight number but wet-leased from ACT Airlines, which provides extra cargo capacity to major airlines.
The airport did not receive any distress signals from the pilots prior to the incident.
No major disruptions to airport operations were expected due to the use of two remaining operational runways.
The airport has suspended operations on its north runway until the aircraft is removed from the sea.
A large emergency response involving over 200 people, fire engines, and boats was deployed.
Hong Kong International Airport has a strong safety record, with only one major fatal crash in 1999 involving a China Airlines flight landing upside down during a typhoon.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A cargo plane operated by Turkish cargo carrier ACT Airlines, under an Emirates flight number, skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) around 3:50 a.m. local time after arriving from Dubai. The Boeing aircraft broke in two upon impact, colliding with an airport security patrol car and pushing it into the sea, resulting in the deaths of two occupants. The four crew members were treated for injuries, and no cargo was on board. The incident occurred without any distress signals from the pilots, and the airport has suspended operations on its north runway while emergency responders, including over 200 personnel, worked to manage the situation. Despite the severity of the accident, the airport's operations remained largely unaffected due to the continued use of two other runways. The event is notable in the context of HKIA’s strong safety record, with only one major fatal crash in 1999 involving a China Airlines flight during a typhoon, underscoring the rarity of such incidents at this major international hub.
title: Two killed as cargo plane skids off runway into the sea in Hong Kong
